survey.question: How has your rabbit's appetite been?
survey.description: Options: None (not eating), Low (eating a little bit), Normal (eating normally)

survey.question: Has your rabbit's stomach been making loud gurgling noises or has it been silent?
survey.description: Options:  Yes (make loud gurgling noise or no sound), No (make normal sound)

survey.question: Has your rabbit been producing no fecal pellets or small, deformed fecal pellets?
survey.description: Options:  Yes (your rabbit's poops are small, deformed or no poops at all), No (your rabbit's poop doesn't change)

survey.question: Has your rabbit been standing in a hunched posture?
Has your rabbit's energy level suddenly decreased?
Has your rabbit been constantly scratching its ears?
Has your rabbit been constantly shaking its head?
Has there been a crust forming/dandruff somewhere on your rabbit's body?
Has your rabbit been drooling?
Has your rabbit had any swollen areas on its body?
Has your rabbit had red ears?
Has your rabbit been trembling, shaking, or experiencing loss of balance?
Has your rabbit suddenly lifted its head?
Has your rabbit been sneezing multiple times a day?
Has your rabbit had watery eyes?
Has your rabbit had a runny nose?
How has your rabbit been breathing?
Has your rabbit's head suddenly tilted?
How frequently has your rabbit been peeing?
survey.description: Options: None (Not peeing), Infrequent (normal), Frequent (peeing more frequently)

survey.question: Has your rabbit's urine been sludgy?
Has your rabbit's urine been bloody?
Has your rabbit lost weight significantly?
Has your rabbit had discharge in its eyes?
Have you noticed any of your rabbit's teeth being overgrown, pointy, or curved in its mouth?
Has your rabbit had any lump?
Has your rabbit lost fur?

diseases.symptoms: Enlargements under skin near jaw. Can occur on other parts of body where there are wounds or scratches.
diseases.prevention: Eliminate sharp objects that can injure the rabbit.
diseases.treatment: Clip the fur around abscess, then lance and remove the pus. Disinfect with peroxide and use an approved antibiotic ointment or powder to promote healing.

diseases.cause: High calcium diet, low water intake, overweight, lack of places to urinate, kidney disease, or cystitis.
diseases.symptoms: Lessening of appetite, fewer or cessation of droppings, blood may appear in the urine, loud painful grinding of the teeth, lethargy, unwillingness to move, hunched posture, pressing their abdomen on the ground, perineal scalding, straining or inability to urinate and passing thick, white, toothpaste like urine.
diseases.prevention: Drink more water, avoid feeding alfalfa hay and high calcium vegestables (kale, carrot tops, spinach, parsley, and spring greens)
diseases.treatment: Urethral calculi are usually removed by flushing the stone back into the bladder and performing a cystotomy to remove it/them from the bladder.

diseases.symptoms: Scabs or a crust start forming at base of inner ear. Mites cause considerable irritation and rabbit will shake its head and try to scratch ears with hind feet.
diseases.prevention: Do not let unaffected rabbits in contact with rabbits that have ear canker.
diseases.treatment: Use a cotton swab to apply mineral, vegetable or olive oil over all visible crust. Usually one or two treatments is sufficient.

diseases.symptoms: A dry scaly skin (dandruff) on the shoulders and back.
diseases.prevention: Prevent contact with affected rabbits, keep clean living conditions.
diseases.treatment: Ivermectin and Revolution (Selamectin) can kill larvae.

diseases.cause: Low fiber diet, stressful environment, dental problems, dehydration or other systemic illnesses, such as liver or kidney disease.
diseases.symptoms: Rabbit will sporadically eat small amounts of feed. A firm mass can be palpated in the stomach. Their fecal pellets become smaller, drier, and eventually stop being produced. Rabbits are not eating well get dehydrrated, lethargy and stop moving.
diseases.prevention: Feed high fiber diet, encourage physical exercise, have your rabbit checked regularly by veterinarian.
diseases.treatment: Fluid therapy, syringe feeding, antibiotic, pain relivers, anti-inflammatory medications.

diseases.cause: Excessively high temperatures (above 85F) and high humidity (above 70%), obesity, poor ventilation, insufficient water and crowding.
diseases.symptoms: Increased respiration rate (panting) prostration, and excessive saliva discharge. Pregnant does and young in the nest box are most susceptible.
diseases.prevention: Provide shade, adequate air movement, and plenty of cool water on a hot day. Wet burlap in cage will aid in cooling.
diseases.treatment: Rabbits suffering from heat exhaustion can be immersed in lukewarm water to reduce body temperature to the normal 101-1040F. Apply a cool compress to the ears.

diseases.cause: An inherited condition characterized by excessive growth of the teeth.
diseases.symptoms: Lower teeth protrude and upper teeth curve into the mouth.
diseases.treatment: veterinarians will use dental burrs on dental drills to file down the incisors and molars, often under anesthesia. If a rabbit is having recurrent dental problems, one long-term solution is to remove the affeted teeth.

diseases.cause: A chronic upper respiratory ailment caused by bacterial infection.
diseases.symptoms: Typical early signs are a nasal discharge, watery eyes, head shaking, sneezing or rattling noise in breathing and a loss of weight. Continual infection may cause rabbits to become sterile.
diseases.prevention: Quarantine all new rabbits for a 3 week period. Cull rabbits that show continuous chronic symptoms of the disease. Reduce stress factors and have good management and sanitation practices.
diseases.treatment: Tetracycline in feed may be effective in an uncomplicated case. For accurate treatment, the organism needs to be cultured and identified.
